Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the clock ticking past midnight. My phone buzzed again—another message from Mia. We’d argued three times this week about our budget, and she wanted to talk, to resolve things before bed. I knew she expected me to be present, to listen, to help us find common ground. But my mind was tangled in the hospital project. Tomorrow was the final inspection, and I had to be certain every detail met safety codes. One missed regulation could put lives at risk. My supervisor’s words echoed in my head: “We can’t afford mistakes.” I felt pulled in two directions—Mia’s voice in my ear, pleading for reassurance, and the silent weight of responsibility pressing down on my shoulders. My heart ached with guilt, knowing I couldn’t give either role what it demanded tonight. I stared at my phone, then back at the plans, feeling the pressure mount, unsure which call to answer first.
